availableProgramScreen.description:
Join the clean energy ecosystem and enroll your home or small business in Olivine’s Energy Program. Your participation will support grid resilience and clean air throughout California, helping to avoid the use of polluting gas fired peaker plants.

Enrollment Benefits

Learn about your energy usage and how small actions can make a difference. Olivine will also help you identify and access incentives or rebates for which you may be eligible.

Participation Benefits

Regardless of where you live in California, everyone has a right to breathe clean air. In times of high grid need or carbon emissions, we will send you notifications to participate in Energy Savings Events. Your participation in these events will help save energy, reduce your bills and support clean air for all Californians. You will be able to track the energy and environmental impact of your participation through our App. Participation in any of these energy savings events is completely voluntary.

Your actions will help support the work of local governments, charities and non-profit organizations that are focused on fighting climate change, promote clean air and help low-income residents. For your participation Olivine will make a donation to the Coalition for Clean Air:www.ccair.org

There is no obligation and it’s free to participate. Sign up today and make a difference. Enrollment is limited to one person per household.

Olivine Energy Program is an Olivine ClimateResponse™ Program™
availableProgramScreen.terms: I have read and agree to the Terms and Conditionsof the Olivine Energy Program and the Olivine Participation Agreement

If you have changed your mind, please click the back arrow to enroll in a program.

availableProgramScreen.description:
The Power Saver Rewards Program is a free and voluntary program offered by PG&E that rewards you for reducing your energy use when the demand for electricity is high.

Program details

Power Saver Rewards events occur on select hot summer days from 4 p.m. to 9 p.m. between May 1 and October 31 during critical times when the demand for electricity is high. You will be notified of an upcoming event the day before the event through push notification or text message.

Program benefits

Prevent rotating power outages and the possibility of the power being out for a much longer period of time. Receive a credit on your bill when you reduce energy during Power Saver Rewards events. Earn $2 for each kilowatt-hour (kWh) of energy saved.
availableProgramScreen.terms: I have read and agree to the Terms and Conditions of the Power Saver Rewards Program.
availableProgramScreen.more: More info available on the program website.

verificationScreen.description: You may be an SCP customer. Please enter the information below to verify your status and enroll in the GridSavvy program. You can find this information on your electricity bill. If you don’t know your PG&E account number, please call 1 (800) 743-5000 for assistance.
verificationScreen.accountNumber: Why do you need my PG&E account number?

modalAccountNumber.title: Attention:
modalAccountNumber.description: Sonoma Clean Power and PG&E work in partnership to bring you electricity. As an SCP customer, SCP procures the power sources for the energy you use in your home or business, while PG&E manages billing and the maintenance of the poles and wires that get that electricity to you. Thanks to public power programs like SCP, customers now have a choice to receive a cleaner mix of energy sources and keep more money in our local community.

notVerifiedScreen.description: You cannot be verified as a SCP customer. If you believe this is in error, please call 800-743-5000 so we can help you complete enrollment.

availableProgramScreen.description:
Thank you for your interest in joining Sonoma Clean Power’s GridSavvy Community. Your participation allows Sonoma Clean Power to power more Sonoma and Mendocino county homes with clean, renewable energy while making energy savings easy for you. This may seem small, but together we can turn the tide on the climate crisis.

Participation Benefits

In times of high stress on the electricity grid, you will be asked to adjust your energy usage for a period of time, usually one to two hours. You will earn $1 for every GridSavvy Community event that you choose to participate in. Once per calendar quarter, you will have the opportunity to cash out your rewards or donate your balance to one of our local charity partners.

Participation is free and completely voluntary. Sign up today and start earning!

webStoreScreen.title: Visit the Web Store
webStoreScreen.description: GridSavvy customers can earn rebates and a $5/month bill credit for purchasing smart devices like smart thermostats, EV charging stations, and heat pump water heaters and connecting them to the GridSavvy Community. You can also connect your existing smart device into the GridSavvy Community to start earning.

recentEnergyHistory.title: Recent energy history
recentEnergyHistory.noData: It can take several days for your meter data to appear in the app. Please check back regularly.

modalEnergyHistory.title: Energy History
modalEnergyHistory.description:
What is a kWh?
A kWh (kilowatt-hour or 1000 watt-hours) is a measure of how much electricity is used and, equals the amount of energy consumed if a 1,000 watt appliance was used for an hour.

What is a Typical day?
A Typical day, such as ‘Typical Friday’ refers to the amount of electricity you typically consume on that day of the week.

Why is there no usage data for the last two days?
It takes about 2 days for your electricity meter data to be provided by your utility, which is why your most recent data for ‘This Week’ is usually missing data for the last 2 days. There may be other days with missing data and that’s OK. The utility will provide it at a later time.

What is Highest and Lowest / Last Week?
Highest/Last Week is the day during the previous week when you consumed the most electricity. The bar in red is the total amount of electricity used that day. Similarly, the Lowest/Last Week is the day during the previous week when you consumed the least amount of electricity. The bar in green is the total amount of electricity used that day.

modalReward.title: Your achievement level reflects how actively you are participating in Energy Events compared to others in the program.

bronze.title: Bronze
bronze.description: You are an active performer and have participated in 30-49% of our Energy Events.

silver.title: Silver
silver.description: You are a great performer and have participated in 50-74% of our Energy Events.

gold.title: Gold
gold.description: You are a top performer and have participated in 75% or more Energy Events.

gridEmissionsContainer.Cont_DataCont_Description_Text: Higher numbers indicate the grid has limited clean energy resources and increased emissions. Reduce electricity use when this number is high.

modalEnvironmentalImpact.title: Environmental Impact
modalEnvironmentalImpact.description:
Did you know that your energy actions can directly impact air quality?

Environmental impact shows your impacts through Energy Events and the cumulative impact of all the program’s participants. Every time you change your energy use in response to an Energy Event, the amount of energy impact gets added to the calculations displayed on the Environmental Impact dashboard.

“Energy Impact” is the total amount of energy you have reduced through participation in events. From that number, we calculate “Emissions Reduction”, which is the total pounds of carbon dioxide that has been avoided by your energy use reductions. “Auto Miles Equivalent”, is what the reduction in carbon dioxide emissions represents in miles driven by a gas powered automobile.

modalEnergyEvent.title: Energy Event
modalEnergyEvent.description:
This view provides information on specific energy events.

The “Energy Event” bar
Represents the electricity you have used during the event.

The “Typical” bar
Represents the electricity you typically use on that day of the week during the same time of day, adjusted for weather.
